body:
# crexcel

[![Build Status](https://travis-ci.org/Monpt7/crexcel.svg?branch=master)](https://travis-ci.org/Monpt7/crexcel)

crexcel is a crystal library to generate XLSX files almost like this [python module](https://github.com/jmcnamara/XlsxWriter)

**Important note :** this library only works with the master branch of Crystal for the moment. 0.24.2 version doesn't work but I hope 0.24.3 will!

## Installation

Add this to your application's `shard.yml`:

```yaml
dependencies:
  crexcel:
    github: Monpt7/crexcel
```

## Usage

```crystal
require "crexcel"
```

A very tiny doc is available here : https://monpt7.github.io/crexcel/

## Contributing

1. Fork it ( https://github.com/Monpt7/crexcel/fork )
2. Create your feature branch (git checkout -b my-new-feature)
3. Commit your changes (git commit -am 'Add some feature')
4. Push to the branch (git push origin my-new-feature)
5. Create a new Pull Request

## Contributors

- [Monpt7](https://github.com/Monpt7) - creator, maintainer

types.name: Workbook
types.doc:
The Workbook Class is the main class of Crexcel.
It create the file which will contains the worksheets.
NOTE: Don't forget to call the close method in order to generate your xlsx file!
types.summary: The Workbook Class is the main class of Crexcel.

constructors.name: new
constructors.doc:
The new method let you create a workbook, you only need one per file you want to generate.

You must give a name to it :

```
my_workbook = Workbook.new("thing.xlsx")
```
NOTE: You are not forced to give the extension, if you type `Workbook.new("thing")`
 it will still create a 'thing.xlsx' file.
constructors.summary: The new method let you create a workbook, you only need one per file you want to generate.

instance_methods.name: add_worksheet
instance_methods.doc:
Call this to add a worksheet to the workbook with a name.

It returns a Worksheet object
```
workbook = Workbook.new("thing.xlsx")
first_worksheet = workbook.add_worksheet("test")
```
instance_methods.summary: Call this to add a worksheet to the workbook with a name.

instance_methods.name: add_worksheet
instance_methods.doc:
Call this to add a worksheet to the workbook without giving it a name.

It returns a Worksheet object
```
workbook = Workbook.new("thing.xlsx")
first_worksheet = workbook.add_worksheet
```
instance_methods.summary: Call this to add a worksheet to the workbook without giving it a name.

def.name: add_worksheet
def.body:
nbr_sheet = @sheets.size + 1
name = "Sheet" + nbr_sheet.to_s
worksheet = Worksheet.new(name)
@sheets << worksheet
worksheet

instance_methods.name: close
instance_methods.doc:
This function close the workbook and generate a xlsx file.
You **MUST** call this function at the end of you script for each Workbook created.
If you don't, this **WILL NOT** generate the xlsx file.
OPTIMIZE: In the future, not closing a Workbook will raise an error
 instead of silently not generate the file.
instance_methods.summary: This function close the workbook and generate a xlsx file.

def.name: close
def.body:
dirs.each_value do |val|
  if Dir.exists?(val)
  else
    Dir.mkdir(val)
  end
end
ArchiveBuilder.new(dirs, @sheets.size)
SharedString.generate_xml(File.join(dirs[:xl], "sharedStrings.xml"))
write_worksheets_xml
write_workbook_xml
write_rels_xml
generate_xlsx
FileUtils.rm_r(dirs[:root])

types.name: Worksheet
types.doc: TODO Write doc for Worksheet class
types.summary: TODO Write doc for Worksheet class

instance_methods.name: get
instance_methods.doc:
Fetch the data at the given x, y postition
```
first_worksheet = workbook.add_worksheet
first_worksheet.write(0, 0, "hello") # Will write "hello" in A1 cell
first_worksheet.get(0, 0)            # => {pos: "A1", value: "hello", type: ""}
```
instance_methods.summary: Fetch the data at the given x, y postition ` first_worksheet = workbook.add_worksheet first_worksheet.write(0, 0, "hello") # Will write "hello" in A1 cell first_worksheet.get(0, 0) # => {pos: "A1", value: "hello", type: ""} `

def.name: get
def.body:
position = int_pos_to_char(pos_x, pos_y)
get_datas.find do |i|
  i[:pos] == position
end || {pos: position, value: "", type: ""}

instance_methods.name: get
instance_methods.doc:
Fetch the data at the given string postition
```
first_worksheet = workbook.add_worksheet
first_worksheet.write(0, 0, "hello") # Will write "hello" in A1 cell
first_worksheet.get("A1")            # => {pos: "A1", value: "hello", type: ""}
```
instance_methods.summary: Fetch the data at the given string postition ` first_worksheet = workbook.add_worksheet first_worksheet.write(0, 0, "hello") # Will write "hello" in A1 cell first_worksheet.get("A1") # => {pos: "A1", value: "hello", type: ""} `

def.name: get

instance_methods.name: write
instance_methods.doc:
Write data in the specified worksheet at specific location
You can precise the type you want

```
first_worksheet = workbook.add_worksheet
first_worksheet.write("A1", "1337", "int") # Will write 1337 as a number
```
**Available types are for now :** string, int
instance_methods.summary: Write data in the specified worksheet at specific location You can precise the type you want
instance_methods.args_string: (position : String, str : Int32 | Int64 | Float64 | String, type_req : String)

def.name: write

instance_methods.name: write
instance_methods.doc:
Same as other write methods, but location is precised differently
```
first_worksheet = workbook.add_worksheet
first_worksheet.write(0, 0, "hello") # Will write "hello" in A1 cell
```
instance_methods.summary: Same as other write methods, but location is precised differently ` first_worksheet = workbook.add_worksheet first_worksheet.write(0, 0, "hello") # Will write "hello" in A1 cell `
instance_methods.args_string: (pos_x : Int32 | Int64, pos_y : Int32 | Int64, str : Int32 | Int64 | Float64 | String, type_req = "")

def.name: write
def.body:
if type_req == ""
  write(int_pos_to_char(pos_x, pos_y), str)
else
  write(int_pos_to_char(pos_x, pos_y), str, type_req)
end

instance_methods.name: write
instance_methods.doc:
Write data in the specified worksheet at specific location

```
first_worksheet = workbook.add_worksheet
first_worksheet.write("A1", "Hello world!")
first_worksheet.write("A2", "1337") # Will write 1337 as a string
first_worksheet.write("B1", 1337)   # Will write 1337 as a number
```
instance_methods.summary: Write data in the specified worksheet at specific location
instance_methods.args_string: (position : String, str : Int32 | Int64 | Float64 | String)

def.name: write

instance_methods.name: write_row
instance_methods.doc:
Will write a row with the provided array of data
```
first_worksheet = workbook.add_worksheet
first_worksheet.write_row(0, ["hello", "world"]) # Will write "hello" in A1 cell and "world" in A2
```
instance_methods.summary: Will write a row with the provided array of data ` first_worksheet = workbook.add_worksheet first_worksheet.write_row(0, ["hello", "world"]) # Will write "hello" in A1 cell and "world" in A2 `
instance_methods.args_string: (pos_y : Int32 | Int64, data : Array(Int32 | Int64 | Float64 | String))

def.name: write_row
def.body:
data.each_index do |i|
  write(i, pos_y, data[i])
end

instance_methods.name: write_row
instance_methods.doc:
Will write a row with the provided array of data
```
first_worksheet = workbook.add_worksheet
first_worksheet.write_row("A", ["hello", "world"]) # Will write "hello" in A1 cell and "world" in A2
```
instance_methods.summary: Will write a row with the provided array of data ` first_worksheet = workbook.add_worksheet first_worksheet.write_row("A", ["hello", "world"]) # Will write "hello" in A1 cell and "world" in A2 `
instance_methods.args_string: (row : String, data : Array(Int32 | Int64 | Float64 | String))

def.name: write_row
def.body:
data.each_index do |i|
  position = "#{row}#{i + 1}"
  write(position, data[i])
end

types.name: Dir
types.doc:
Objects of class `Dir` are directory streams representing directories in the underlying file system.
They provide a variety of ways to list directories and their contents.

The directory used in these examples contains the two regular files (`config.h` and `main.rb`),
the parent directory (`..`), and the directory itself (`.`).

See also: `File`.
types.summary: Objects of class Dir are directory streams representing directories in the underlying file system.
